newsitem.title: INDIA: Year of tumult in Indian politics.
newsitem.headline: Year of tumult in Indian politics.

text.p: The Congress Party's decision to withdraw support from Prime Minister H.D. Deve Gowda's centre-left alliance casts doubt on the survival of the United Front government.
Following is a chronology since last year's general election.
April-May 1996 - General election held over several weeks defeats ruling Congress Party and makes Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) the largest single party in parliament.
May 16 - BJP leader Atal Bihari Vajpayee sworn in as prime minister without assurance of majority support in parliament.
May 28 - Vajpayee resigns as prime minister because of impeding defeat in parliamentary vote.
June 1 - H.D. Deve Gowda sworn in at head of United Front, a coalition of 13 parties which Congress supports but does not join.
June 28 - Communists join government for first time since independence from Britain in 1947.
July 11 - Delhi court summons Congress president P.V. Narasimha Rao to testify as co-accused in cheating case.
September 22 - Rao resigns as president of Congress Party.
September 23 - Sitaram Kesri elected Congress president.
October 11 - Uttar Pradesh state election returns a hung assembly; local power struggle sharpens conflicts between Congress and coalition parties at national level.
February 28 - Government strengthened by daring, market friendly budget.
March 19 -Bahujan Samaj Party (BSP), a powerful low-caste party, deserts alliance with Congress in Uttar Pradesh to form government with BJP.
March 30 - Congress withdraws support from United Front.
